Title: Proof: Series converges $\implies $ the limit of the sequence is zero
Content: I've been using the sentence: If a series converges then the limit of the sequence is zero as a criterion to prove that a series diverges (when $\lim \neq 0$) and I can understand the rationale behind it, but I can't find a formal proof . Can you help me?
AcceptedAnswer:
Yes. $$\lim_{n \to \infty} \left ( \sum_{k = 1}^{n + 1} a_k - \sum_{k = 1}^{n} a_k \right ) = \lim_{n \to \infty} a_{n + 1} $$
And both sums will converge to the same number so the limit is zero. This is by far the easiest proof I know. This is the Cauchy criterion in disguise by the way, so you could use that too.
